rev.diff:
Line 95: Line 95:
On 14 March, security forces raided an apartment shared by four Western journalists and deported them. [[Reporters Without Borders]] condemned the action and noted that two other foreign journalists were also deported two days earlier. The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] also condemned the expulsions. They also said that two Yemeni journalists informed them that a group of 20 people, believed to be government supporters, went to the Journalists Syndicate in Sanaa a day earlier{{When|date=March 2011}} and threatened to burn it down.<ref name="AJYemen15Mar">{{cite news |title=Yemen deports foreign journalists |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011314212132903514.html |newspaper= |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> They further said that Yemeni journalists are facing increasing harassment.<ref>{{cite web|author=Attacks on journalists in Yemen, Sudan amid street protests |url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/attacks-on-journalists-in-yemen-sudan-amid-street.php |title=Attacks on journalists in Yemen, Sudan amid street protests - Committee to Protect Journalists |publisher=Cpj.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
On 14 March, security forces raided an apartment shared by four Western journalists and deported them. [[Reporters Without Borders]] condemned the action and noted that two other foreign journalists were also deported two days earlier. The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] also condemned the expulsions. They also said that two Yemeni journalists informed them that a group of 20 people, believed to be government supporters, went to the Journalists Syndicate in Sanaa a day earlier{{When|date=March 2011}} and threatened to burn it down.<ref name="AJYemen15Mar">{{cite news |title=Yemen deports foreign journalists |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011314212132903514.html |newspaper= |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> They further said that Yemeni journalists are facing increasing harassment.<ref>{{cite web|author=Attacks on journalists in Yemen, Sudan amid street protests |url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/attacks-on-journalists-in-yemen-sudan-amid-street.php |title=Attacks on journalists in Yemen, Sudan amid street protests - Committee to Protect Journalists |publisher=Cpj.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
â   â
==Domestic Responses==
  â
On 27 January, Yemeni Interior Minister [[Mutaher al-Masri]] said that "Yemen is not like Tunisia."<ref name="Yemen isnt Tunisia">{{cite news
  â
| url= http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2011/01/27/Yemen-isnt-Tunisia-government-says/UPI-42591296153057/
  â
| title= Yemen isn't Tunisia, government says
  â
| publisher= United Press International
  â
| date= Jan. 27, 2011
  â
| accessdate= }}</ref>
  â   â
On 2 February, President Ali Abdullah Saleh said that he would freeze the constitutional amendment process under way. He also vowed not to pass on the reins of power to his son: "No extension, no inheritance, no resetting the clock;"<ref>{{cite news
  â
| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/2011228541277951.html
  â
| title= Yemen president not to extend term
  â
| publisher= [[Al-Jazeera English]]
  â
| date= 2 February 2011
  â
| accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref> and that he would quit in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lina Sinjab |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12343166 |title=BBC News - Yemen President Ali Abdullah Saleh to quit in 2013 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2010-10-30 |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> He also called for [[national unity government]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Mazen |first=Maram |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-02/mubarak-step-down-pledge-fails-to-calm-protests-as-unrest-spreads-to-yemen.html |title=Gunfire in Cairo as Mubarak Allies Battle Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> He further promised direct elections of provincial governors and to re-open voter registration for the April election after complaints that about 1.5 million Yemenis could not sign on to the voter rolls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121210345525985.html |title=Middle East rulers make concessions |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-02-12 |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> On 1 March, Saleh blamed the United States and Israel over the conflict.<ref name="Al Jazeera. Headlines" />
  â   â
On 10 March, he announced a [[Yemeni constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum]] on moving to a parliamentary system of government would be held later in the year. A spokesperson for the anti-government protesters said this was "too little, too late."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12697077 |title=Yemen: President Saleh announces 'parliamentary system' |publisher=BBC News |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2011-03-11}}</ref> He said a new constitution would guarantee the separation of legislative and executive powers and prepare for a new election.<ref>{{cite news |title=New constitution promised for Yemen |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131073622898186.html |newspaper= |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> On 20 March, Saleh fired the cabinet, Saleh fired all members of his [[Cabinet of Yemen]] on the same day including Prime Minister [[Ali Muhammad Mujawar]] and vice-Prime Ministers [[Al-Rashad Mouhmmed alaÃ¯my]], [[Abdul-Karim Al-Ar'haby]] and [[Sadiq Amin Abu-Rass]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Yemeni president fires government |author=[[BBC]] |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12800887 |newspaper= |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref> but asked them to remain in a caretaker role until he forms a new one.<ref name="AJYemen20Mar">{{cite news |title=Yemen president fires cabinet |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011320180579476.html |newspaper= |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=20 March 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The leader of the [[Yemeni Congregation for Reform]], the largest opposition party in Yemen, Mohammed al-Sabry, stated, "We want constitutional amendments but we want amendments that don't lead to the continuance of the ruler and the inheritance of power to his children."<ref name="afreuters" /> He also doubted Saleh's pledge not to seek re-election. Al-Sabry said Saleh made a promise in 2006 not to run, but then failed to fulfill his pledge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110202/D9L4JL1O0.html |title=Yemeni president says he won't seek another term |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref>
  â   â
===Resignations from the ruling party and government===
  â
{{See also|Cabinet of Yemen}}
  â
; 5 March 2011
  â
* Head of the finance committee of parliament [[Fathi Tawfiq Abdulrahim]]<ref name="jazeerampsmarch5">[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113514455840795.html Yemen MPs quit ruling party], ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'', 5 March 2011</ref>
  â
* Deputy [[Ministry of Culture (Yemen)|Minister of Culture]] [[Sam Yahya Al-Ahmar]]<ref name="jazeerampsmarch5"/>
  â
* Deputy [[Ministry of Youth and Sports (Yemen)|Minister of Youth and Sports]] [[Hashid Abdullah al-Ahmar]]<ref name="jazeerampsmarch5"/>
  â
* MP [[Ali Al-Imrani]], from al-Baida province<ref name="jazeerampsmarch5"/>
  â
* Businessman Nabil Al-Khameri<ref name="jazeerampsmarch5"/>
  â
; 18 March 2011
  â
* [[Ministry of Tourism (Yemen)|Minister of Tourism]] [[Nabil Hasan al-Faqih]], from his post and the ruling party<ref name="guardianlivemarch18">[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/mar/18/libya-military-action-live-updates#block-55 Libya military action: live updates], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 18 March 2011</ref><ref name="yahooAUmarch20-quit"/>
  â
* Head of the party's foreign affairs committee, Dr. [[Mohammed Abdulmajeed al-Qubati]]<ref name="guardianlivemarch18"/><ref name="yahooAUmarch20-quit"/>
  â
* Minister of Culture and Yemeni Shura Council member [[Abdulwahab al-Rawhani]], from the ministry and council<ref name="guardianlivemarch18"/><ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-03/19/c_13786741.htm Death toll rises to 45 as emergency declared in Yemen amid mounting protests], ''[[Xinhuanet]]'', 19 March 2011</ref>
  â
* Ambassador to Russia Dr. [[Mohammed Saleh Ahmed Al-Helali]]<ref name="guardianlivemarch18"/>
  â
* Party's central committee member [[Jalal Faqira]] who also heads the political science department at [[Sanaa University]]<ref name="guardianlivemarch18"/>
  â
* 50 professors<ref name="guardianlivemarch18"/>
  â   â
;19 March 2011
  â
* Assistant Secretary General of the Cabinet [[Mohammad Sewar]]<ref name="yahooAUmarch20-quit">[http://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/-/world/9041205/yemeni-troops-on-streets-as-two-party-members-quit/ Yemeni Troops On Streets As Two Party Members Quit], ''[[Yahoo!]]'', 20 March 2011</ref><ref name="newsYemenMar19-quit">[http://www.newsyemen.net/en/view_news.asp?sub_no=3_2011_03_19_40330Yemen: officials resign from ruling party following violence against protesters], ''[[News Yemen]]'', 19 March 2011</ref>
  â
* Head of the state news agency and a ruling party member [[Nasr Taha Mustafa]]<ref name="guardian1">[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/19/yemen-sanaa-state-emergency-troops Security forces blanket Yemen capital to enforce state of emergency], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 19 March 2011</ref>
  â
* Ambassador to Lebanon [[FayÃ§al Amine Abourrass]]<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5igr1rxe02d-TWWIdydUaSR8yi4nA?docId=CNG.0571c1ac6567bdad38af266d2e0abe05.531 |title=AFP: Yemen rights minister resigns to protest crackdown |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lorientlejour.com/category/Liban/article/695234/Demission_de_lambassadeur_du_Yemen_au_Liban_suite_au_massacre_de_Sanaa.html |title=L'Orient-Le Jour |publisher=Lorientlejour.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-21}}</ref>
  â
* [[Mohamed Saleh Qara'a]], a prominent member of the ruling party<ref name="guardian1"/>
  â   â
;20 March 2011
  â
* [[Human Rights Ministry (Yemen)|Human Rights Minister]] [[Huda al-Baan]], from her post and the ruling party<ref name="inquirer1">[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view/20110320-326612/Yemen-rights-minister-resigns-to-protest-crackdown Yemen rights minister resigns to protest crackdown], Newsinfo.inquirer.net, 19 March 2011</ref>
  â
* Undersecretary at the Human Rights Ministry [[Ali Taysir]], from his post<ref name="inquirer1"/>
  â   â
;21 March 2011
  â
* Representative to the Arab League<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Algeria<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Belgium [[Abdul-Wali al-Shameri]]<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to China [[Marwan Abdullah Abdulwahab Noman]]<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Czech Republic<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Egypt [[Abdul-Wali al-Shameri]]<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Germany<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Indonesia<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Iraq [[Abdul-Wali al-Shameri]]<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Jordan [[Shaea Muhssin]]<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Kuwait Dr. [[Khaled Sheikh]]<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Oman<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Pakistan<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Saudi Arabia [[Mohammed Ali al-Ahwal]]<ref name=guardianlivemarch21">[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/mar/21/yemen-army-commanders-defect Yemen unrest - live coverage], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 March 2011</ref><ref name="jazeeralivemarch21">[http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/middle-east/yemen-live-blog-march-21 Yemen Live Blog - March 21], ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'', 21 March 2011</ref>
  â
* Ambassador to Spain<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to Syria [[Abdel-Wahhab Tawaf]]<ref>{{cite news |title= Yemen ambassador to Syria resigns from post, party |author=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=213120 |newspaper= |date=21 March 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref>
  â
* Ambassador to Qatar<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Ambassador to the United Nations [[Abdullah al-Saidi]]<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Charge dâaffairs to Tunisia<ref name="jazeeralivemarch21"/>
  â
* Major General [[Ali Mohsen al-Ahmar]] (Ali Mohsen Saleh), head of the North Western Military Zone, and three of his brigadiers:<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/21/yemen-regime-army-chiefs-defect Yemen showdown looms as army loyalties divide], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 March 2011</ref><ref name="jazeeraarmymarch21">[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011320180579476.html Top army commanders defect in Yemen], ''[[Al Jazeera English]], 21 March 2011</ref>
  â
** Brigadier [[Mohammed Ali Mohsen]], head of the Eastern Division<ref name="jazeeraarmymarch21"/>
  â
** Brigadier [[Hameed Al Koshebi]], head of brigade 310 in Omran area<ref name="jazeeraarmymarch21"/>
  â
** Brigadier [[Nasser Eljahori]], head of brigade 121<ref name="jazeeraarmymarch21"/>
  â
* 60 officers of the province of Hadramout and 50 officers from the Ministry of Interior{{citation needed|date=March 2011}}
  â
* [[Abdallah al-Qahdi]], a senior military general from Aden<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/21/yemen-military-commanders-opposition-tanks Yemen military commanders join opposition as tanks take to the streets], Tom Finn, ''[[The Guardian]], 21 March 2011</ref>
  â   â
==International reactions==
  â
* {{flagicon|Canada}} On March 6, 2011 - Canadian Foreign Affairs Department said, "Canadians should leave Yemen as soon as possible, the Department of Foreign Affairs reiterated Sunday, as new political violence swept the Middle Eastern nation."<ref>{{cite news|title = Leave Yemen, Ottawa warns Canadians |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/03/06/yemen-travel-warning.html}}</ref>
  â
* {{flagicon|UK}} British [[Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] said he was "deeply concerned" by the "unacceptable violence" used against protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12514696 |title=BBC News - Hague condemns violence in Libya, Bahrain and Yemen |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> The government announced that in light of the unrest it was considering revoking some arms export licenses stating that "licenses will not be issued when officials judge that there is a risk that the exports may provoke regional or internal conflicts or be used to facilitate internal repression."<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =UK accused of selling arms to Bahrain| work =| publisher =Al Jazeera English | date =2011-02-18| url =http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112184122210251.html | doi =| accessdate =2011-02-18}}</ref>
  â
* {{flagicon|USA}} President [[Barack Obama]] said that he was "deeply concerned" by the violence.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carey |first=Glen |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-17/bahrain-security-forces-kill-two-people-overnight-human-rights-groups-say.html |title=Bahrain's King Seeks Talks With Foes Amid Clashes in Region |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2011-02-18 |accessdate=2011-02-24}}</ref>
  â
:During a trip to Yemen, United States [[US State Department|Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said she would be working not just at a military [[United States â Yemen relations|cooperation]] but also a "comprehensive strategy" aimed at resolving Yemen's "myriad problems." She also said that "Yemen recognises the threat AQAP poses to it and it has become increasingly committed to a broad-based counter-terrorism strategy. At the same time, we are committed to a balanced approach towards Yemen which includes social, economic and political assistance. We face a common threat by the terrorists in Al-Qaeda. We are focused not just on short-term threats but on long-term challenges." She also signaled a "joint vision for a unified, stable, democratic and prosperous Yemen where civil society had the room to operate and Al-Qaeda did not."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=169704&language=en |title=Al-ManarTV:: Clinton in Yemen: We Face Common Terrorist Threat 11/01/2011 |publisher=Almanar.com.lb |date=2011-01-14 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> U.S. State Department spokesman Philip Crowley told reporters that the US government backs the right of Yemenis to "express themselves and assemble freely".<ref name="US backs Yemenis">{{cite news
  â
| url= http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jO7qKYr540pwAsWnx-eTCpjpoxUg?docId=CNG.b27ce982d5a2c46fdde0c964ca0fcea9.ef1
  â
| title= US backs Yemeni right to protest
  â
| publisher= [[Agence France-Presse]]
  â
| date= 27 January 2011
  â
| accessdate= }}</ref> The US also later said that it had hopes reform attempts to stave off protests similar to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/03/AR2011020300546.html |title=US Officials: US-Egypt discuss Mubarak quitting |publisher=[[Washingtonpost.com]] |date= |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> The [[United States Ambassador to Yemen|U.S. Embassy in Yemen]] wrote in a statement that it had seen "a disturbing rise in the number and violence of attacks against Yemeni citizens gathering peacefully to express their views on the current political situation," adding, "We have also seen reports that Government of Yemen officials were present during these attacks," and asked the Yemeni government to "prevent any further attacks on peaceful demonstrations."<ref name="Sudarsan Raghavan">{{cite news
  â
| last= Raghavan
  â
| first= Sudarsan
  â
| url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021804066.html
  â
| title= In Yemen, government loyalists harden their attacks on protesters
  â
| publisher= [[washingtonpost.com]]
  â
| date= February 18, 2011
  â
| accessdate= }}</ref>
  â
:After cleric [[Abdul Majid al-Zindani]], a one-time mentor of [[Osama bin Laden]], publicly called for an Islamic state to replace Saleh, Garry Reid, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Special Operations and Combating Terrorism, said Saleh's government was "the best partner we'll have [against al-Qaeda], and hopefully it will survive."<ref>{{cite news|title=Powerful Cleric Urges Islamic Rule in Yemen|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/world/middleeast/02yemen.html|accessdate=March 2, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 1, 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
;Financial markets
  â
On 2 February, [[brent crude]] crossed US$100 on concern over instability.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Brent-oil-tops-103-on-Egypt-violence-Yemen-2011-02-03T114224Z-UPDATE-6 |title=Brent oil tops $103 on Egypt violence, Yemen-UPDATE 6 |publisher=Forexyard.com |date=2008-09-26 |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> The following day, crude oil rose for the fifth day in a row on speculation of spreading protests and the prospect of uncertainty.<ref>{{cite web|last=Regan |first=Michael P. |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/japanese-stocks-decline-on-earnings-unrest-in-egypt-crude-copper-climb.html |title=Euro Slides as Trichet Damps Rate-Increase Speculation; U.S. Stocks Fall |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref>
  â   â
Regional financial stock market indices fell on 20 February on concern of spreading instability.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hankir |first=Zahra |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-20/dubai-shares-drop-most-this-month-on-growing-mideast-unrest-emaar-falls.html |title=Dubai Shares Drop as Mideast Unrest Sparks Risk Aversion; Emaar, Zain Fall |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2011-02-20 |accessdate=2011-02-24}}</ref>
 
==Protest timeline==
==Protest timeline==

==Domestic Responses==
  +
On 27 January, Yemeni Interior Minister [[Mutaher al-Masri]] said that "Yemen is not like Tunisia."<ref name="Yemen isnt Tunisia">{{cite news
  +
| url= http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2011/01/27/Yemen-isnt-Tunisia-government-says/UPI-42591296153057/
  +
| title= Yemen isn't Tunisia, government says
  +
| publisher= United Press International
  +
| date= Jan. 27, 2011
  +
| accessdate= }}</ref>
  +   +
On 2 February, President Ali Abdullah Saleh said that he would freeze the constitutional amendment process under way. He also vowed not to pass on the reins of power to his son: "No extension, no inheritance, no resetting the clock;"<ref>{{cite news
  +
| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/2011228541277951.html
  +
| title= Yemen president not to extend term
  +
| publisher= [[Al-Jazeera English]]
  +
| date= 2 February 2011
  +
| accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref> and that he would quit in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lina Sinjab |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12343166 |title=BBC News - Yemen President Ali Abdullah Saleh to quit in 2013 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2010-10-30 |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> He also called for [[national unity government]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Mazen |first=Maram |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-02/mubarak-step-down-pledge-fails-to-calm-protests-as-unrest-spreads-to-yemen.html |title=Gunfire in Cairo as Mubarak Allies Battle Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> He further promised direct elections of provincial governors and to re-open voter registration for the April election after complaints that about 1.5 million Yemenis could not sign on to the voter rolls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121210345525985.html |title=Middle East rulers make concessions |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-02-12 |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> On 1 March, Saleh blamed the United States and Israel over the conflict.<ref name="Al Jazeera. Headlines" />
  +   +
On 10 March, he announced a [[Yemeni constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum]] on moving to a parliamentary system of government would be held later in the year. A spokesperson for the anti-government protesters said this was "too little, too late."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12697077 |title=Yemen: President Saleh announces 'parliamentary system' |publisher=BBC News |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2011-03-11}}</ref> He said a new constitution would guarantee the separation of legislative and executive powers and prepare for a new election.<ref>{{cite news |title=New constitution promised for Yemen |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131073622898186.html |newspaper= |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> On 20 March, Saleh fired the cabinet, Saleh fired all members of his [[Cabinet of Yemen]] on the same day including Prime Minister [[Ali Muhammad Mujawar]] and vice-Prime Ministers [[Al-Rashad Mouhmmed alaÃ¯my]], [[Abdul-Karim Al-Ar'haby]] and [[Sadiq Amin Abu-Rass]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Yemeni president fires government |author=[[BBC]] |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12800887 |newspaper= |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref> but asked them to remain in a caretaker role until he forms a new one.<ref name="AJYemen20Mar">{{cite news |title=Yemen president fires cabinet |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011320180579476.html |newspaper= |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=20 March 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
The leader of the [[Yemeni Congregation for Reform]], the largest opposition party in Yemen, Mohammed al-Sabry, stated, "We want constitutional amendments but we want amendments that don't lead to the continuance of the ruler and the inheritance of power to his children."<ref name="afreuters" /> He also doubted Saleh's pledge not to seek re-election. Al-Sabry said Saleh made a promise in 2006 not to run, but then failed to fulfill his pledge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110202/D9L4JL1O0.html |title=Yemeni president says he won't seek another term |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref>
  +   +
===Resignations from the ruling party and government===
  +
{{See also|Cabinet of Yemen}}
  +
; 5 March 2011
  +
* Head of the finance committee of parliament [[Fathi Tawfiq Abdulrahim]]<ref name="jazeerampsmarch5">[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113514455840795.html Yemen MPs quit ruling party], ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'', 5 March 2011</ref>

  +   +
==International reactions==
  +
* {{flagicon|Canada}} On March 6, 2011 - Canadian Foreign Affairs Department said, "Canadians should leave Yemen as soon as possible, the Department of Foreign Affairs reiterated Sunday, as new political violence swept the Middle Eastern nation."<ref>{{cite news|title = Leave Yemen, Ottawa warns Canadians |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/03/06/yemen-travel-warning.html}}</ref>
  +
* {{flagicon|UK}} British [[Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] said he was "deeply concerned" by the "unacceptable violence" used against protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12514696 |title=BBC News - Hague condemns violence in Libya, Bahrain and Yemen |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> The government announced that in light of the unrest it was considering revoking some arms export licenses stating that "licenses will not be issued when officials judge that there is a risk that the exports may provoke regional or internal conflicts or be used to facilitate internal repression."<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =UK accused of selling arms to Bahrain| work =| publisher =Al Jazeera English | date =2011-02-18| url =http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112184122210251.html | doi =| accessdate =2011-02-18}}</ref>
  +
* {{flagicon|USA}} President [[Barack Obama]] said that he was "deeply concerned" by the violence.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carey |first=Glen |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-17/bahrain-security-forces-kill-two-people-overnight-human-rights-groups-say.html |title=Bahrain's King Seeks Talks With Foes Amid Clashes in Region |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2011-02-18 |accessdate=2011-02-24}}</ref>
  +
:During a trip to Yemen, United States [[US State Department|Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said she would be working not just at a military [[United States â Yemen relations|cooperation]] but also a "comprehensive strategy" aimed at resolving Yemen's "myriad problems." She also said that "Yemen recognises the threat AQAP poses to it and it has become increasingly committed to a broad-based counter-terrorism strategy. At the same time, we are committed to a balanced approach towards Yemen which includes social, economic and political assistance. We face a common threat by the terrorists in Al-Qaeda. We are focused not just on short-term threats but on long-term challenges." She also signaled a "joint vision for a unified, stable, democratic and prosperous Yemen where civil society had the room to operate and Al-Qaeda did not."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=169704&language=en |title=Al-ManarTV:: Clinton in Yemen: We Face Common Terrorist Threat 11/01/2011 |publisher=Almanar.com.lb |date=2011-01-14 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> U.S. State Department spokesman Philip Crowley told reporters that the US government backs the right of Yemenis to "express themselves and assemble freely".<ref name="US backs Yemenis">{{cite news
  +
| url= http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jO7qKYr540pwAsWnx-eTCpjpoxUg?docId=CNG.b27ce982d5a2c46fdde0c964ca0fcea9.ef1
  +
| title= US backs Yemeni right to protest
  +
| publisher= [[Agence France-Presse]]
  +
| date= 27 January 2011
  +
| accessdate= }}</ref> The US also later said that it had hopes reform attempts to stave off protests similar to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/03/AR2011020300546.html |title=US Officials: US-Egypt discuss Mubarak quitting |publisher=[[Washingtonpost.com]] |date= |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> The [[United States Ambassador to Yemen|U.S. Embassy in Yemen]] wrote in a statement that it had seen "a disturbing rise in the number and violence of attacks against Yemeni citizens gathering peacefully to express their views on the current political situation," adding, "We have also seen reports that Government of Yemen officials were present during these attacks," and asked the Yemeni government to "prevent any further attacks on peaceful demonstrations."<ref name="Sudarsan Raghavan">{{cite news
  +
| last= Raghavan
  +
| first= Sudarsan
  +
| url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021804066.html
  +
| title= In Yemen, government loyalists harden their attacks on protesters
  +
| publisher= [[washingtonpost.com]]
  +
| date= February 18, 2011
  +
| accessdate= }}</ref>
  +
:After cleric [[Abdul Majid al-Zindani]], a one-time mentor of [[Osama bin Laden]], publicly called for an Islamic state to replace Saleh, Garry Reid, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Special Operations and Combating Terrorism, said Saleh's government was "the best partner we'll have [against al-Qaeda], and hopefully it will survive."<ref>{{cite news|title=Powerful Cleric Urges Islamic Rule in Yemen|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/world/middleeast/02yemen.html|accessdate=March 2, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 1, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
;Financial markets
  +
On 2 February, [[brent crude]] crossed US$100 on concern over instability.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Brent-oil-tops-103-on-Egypt-violence-Yemen-2011-02-03T114224Z-UPDATE-6 |title=Brent oil tops $103 on Egypt violence, Yemen-UPDATE 6 |publisher=Forexyard.com |date=2008-09-26 |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> The following day, crude oil rose for the fifth day in a row on speculation of spreading protests and the prospect of uncertainty.<ref>{{cite web|last=Regan |first=Michael P. |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/japanese-stocks-decline-on-earnings-unrest-in-egypt-crude-copper-climb.html |title=Euro Slides as Trichet Damps Rate-Increase Speculation; U.S. Stocks Fall |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref>
  +   +
Regional financial stock market indices fell on 20 February on concern of spreading instability.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hankir |first=Zahra |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-20/dubai-shares-drop-most-this-month-on-growing-mideast-unrest-emaar-falls.html |title=Dubai Shares Drop as Mideast Unrest Sparks Risk Aversion; Emaar, Zain Fall |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2011-02-20 |accessdate=2011-02-24}}</ref>
